The empirical findings presented in Tables
III
to
V
provide support for the following
narrative: exposure to high school courses on the 1991 Colombian Constitution is asso-
ciated with a more favorable attitude towards gender equality, particularly among men.
Furthermore, it leads to a diminished perception of sex discrimination, particularly among
women. These findings suggest that the hypothesized change in social norms primarily
involves altering men’s attitudes towards gender equality. This shift in stance may have
contributed to women perceiving reduced instances of sex discrimination and experiencing
increased participation in the labor market (as indicated in Tables
I
and
II
). This hypothe-
sis, while broadly formulated, aligns with specific aspects of Colombian culture, notably the
prevailing male-dominated labor market where women are often relegated to the domestic
sphere (
Iregui-Boh´orquez
et al.
). Furthermore, this hypothesis is in line with the idea
put forth by
’s that promoting women’s rights requires men to have incentives to share
power with women.
Work and Home Spheres
In the preceding subsection, we briefly discussed the role of men in facilitating the
transformation of social norms that affected women’s participation in the labor market.
However, we need to provide more clarity on this matter.
In this subsection, we will
delve deeper into this topic by addressing the following questions: Which women are the
beneficiaries of men’s most favorable views on gender equality? Are these views limited to
women residing within the households of these men (e.g., their wives or daughters)? Or do
they extend to women beyond their immediate households? Although the analysis in this
subsection is exploratory in nature and the results are presented at a broader level, they
provide valuable insights into the specific mechanisms underlying our main findings.
In Table
VI
, we examine whether women’s increased labor market participation, re-
sulting from exposure to high school courses on the 1991 Colombian Constitution, can
be attributed to their male partners’ more favorable attitude towards gender equality.
It is important to note that the attitude of an individual’s partner towards gender equality can be
influenced by the treatment, making this variable a “bad control.” Therefore, the interpretation of these
results should be exercised with caution.
The estimates reveal no statistically significant difference between women who have part-
ners supportive of gender equality (columns (1) to (4)) and those without such partners
(columns (5) to (8)). This suggests that women’s increased participation in the labor mar-
ket is unlikely due to greater support or fewer barriers imposed by their male partners.
The estimates presented in Table
A1
in Appendix
further support these findings, indicating that
exposure to high school courses on the 1991 Colombian Constitution increase men’s awareness of gender
equality regardless of their role as household heads.
